intro: Haplopappus uniflorus, commonly known as the single-flowered pappus, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky habitats and has small, narrow leaves. Its flowers are yellow and produce a single floret, which is a unique feature among its relatives. The plant is adapted to arid environments and plays a role in local ecosystems by providing nectar for pollinators.
